section.title: Leaf Collection and drying
section.para:
Litter is collected from 10 0.92 × 0.92 m leaf collectors within each of the gradient plots. The litter traps are approximately 1 m high. Litter is collected at the end of each quarter (monthly in the autumn):
Quarter 1: April – June Quarter 2: July – September Quarter 3: October – December Quarter 4: January – March
After the litter is collected, the samples are sorted into several categories:
Deciduous leaves Pine needles Rhododendron leaves Other (loose bark, seeds, nuts, loose lichens, etc.) Fine twigs (0-2.5 cm diameter) Medium twigs (2.5-10 cm diameter)
The samples are then dried at 65° C for 48 hours or until dry. The samples are then weighed to the nearest 0.01 g. After weighing, the samples are combined from each category/site and processed in a Wiley mill before being placed in scintillation vials for nutrient analysis (1 sample of each is preserved for archiving).

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: CWT Study Site WS18 -- Watershed 18 in the Coweeta Basin, North Carolina, USA. Grady Branch Watershed. The first hydrologic records for this site began on 7/03/1936. The weir type for this watershed is a 120 degree V-notch. This is a control watershed that has been undisturbed since 1927.

CWT Study Site WS27 -- Watershed 27 in the Coweeta Basin, North Carolina, USA. Hard Luck Creek Watershed. The first hydrologic records from this watershed date to 11/02/1946. The weir is a 120 degree V notch. This a control watershed, but it was partially defoliated by fall cankerworm infestations from 1972 to 1979.

abstract.para: The Coweeta LTER Research Program has evolved since 1980 from a site-based to a site- and region-based project examining the effects of disturbance and environmental gradients on biogeochemical cycling, and the underlying watershed ecosystem processes that regulate and respond to those cycles. The current interdisciplinary research integrates ecological and socioeconomic components across 54,000 km2 of the southern Appalachian Mountains, a biogeophysical and socioeconomic region in which evolutionary and historical processes converge (Whittaker 1956, Markusen 1987, Barnes 1991, Kretzschmar et al. 1993, Bailey 1996). Our research objective in 2002-2008 is to advance scientific understanding of the spatial, temporal, and decision-making components of land use and land-use change in the southern Appalachian Mountains over the last 200 years, and forecast patterns into the future 30 years. Our guiding hypothesis is that the frequency, intensity, and extent of land use represents human decision-making in response to socioeconomic and biogeophysical conditions with consequences that cascade through ecosystems.
